Dear Sir,

Yours of May 8th is read. In regard to the special questions in regard to the "Demos" I will like replies.

M. L. Mrs. Duplex who was a working partner in the "Demos" married and decided to join B.C. as financial returns from the paper were very small.

M. 2. Before my father died my eldest brother Douglas worked in the office with father. He enlisted with Lord Strathcona's Horse and went to South Africa returning in 1903. Then he went to Red Deer, Edmonton, Zacora and finally to Vancouver B.C. Then he lives in the Province until he retired - died in 1956. After Duplex left for the Pacific coast over and worked a couple years with the Esquimalt.
Dear Mr. MacKinnon,

I am writing to you in May 1953. I am interested in applying for the position of Special Assistant in the Department of Finance and Planning in B.C., as per attached application form.

No. 1. I am a single man, aged 28 years, residing at 123 Main Street, Vancouver, B.C.

No. 2. Before my marriage, I worked as an accountant in the Office of the Auditor General of British Columbia.

I am enclosing my resume and references.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

[Address]
2. Brother Harry—then when I was in 1901 my sister Ethel went into the office and carried on—we were all practical printers while Ethel was running the paper after Father died in his old age young and Lewis alone.

3. You father made the living for our family nine children out of the paper—this is where our outside interests—were very luxurious living—myself added—our life was simpler in those days—Mother worked hard and we who worked in the office just for the chance to work and share what she had.

4. Father gathered the news also delivered the paper locally—we had a horse and buggy and the paper was taken to the east end called Coaster in the AM and to the west end in the afternoon (upto Emmanuel College and St. Mary's Church) the closing corner for their papers was near the press.

The policy of the family was always to uphold the government of the day. For John & Macdonalds during the rebellion and further him supported the volunteers and organized defense during the rebellion. He was a Fenian Raid Veteran (I have his medal here) and had attended Military College in Kingston so was better qualified than most to organize defenses. During the rebellion many people opened their homes to farmers in the district and had in several months alone ten people protected or them in our home and the property. One was used as sleeping quarters in the patrol. People add most disastrous effects to the experience in my year late we will had the P.I.O. Round and occasionally calling for some necessary type. I might add here that when people were asked to make statements of their rebellion losses my father put in for very nominal sum - about $200 - albeit the paper had been suspended for several months and he had fed such a large house hold and suffered much discomfor, he contended he had only done his duty in
The precise nature of the accusations made against the defendant during the investigation and proceedings of the court remains unclear due to the destruction of the original documents.

He was a former naval veteran who had attended military college in Kingston upon Hull (not listed separately).

When questioned regarding his involvement in the case, he claimed that he had never been present at the scene of the alleged offense.

The prosecution presented evidence that he had been seen near the location of the crime several months prior to its occurrence.

The defense argued that he had been away from the area during the relevant time frame.

Further investigation revealed that he had indeed been present at the scene of the crime, but he claimed he had been there for a different purpose.

The court found him guilty of the charges brought against him.
Making such efforts to defend his home. Unfortunately many others did not share this belief and several fortresses were founded on inflated hopes and dreams.

Hope this is along the line you want. I have no wish to see the early days recorded or remembered because I feel that in the early days the foundations were laid. What we have now is a magnificent superstructure far surpassing the dreams of those early adventurers. Isn't it a super structure so what of the foundation? We should not forget that—and I think it was well and truly laid by those men who let my father looked for nothing more than to make this a country to live in. A newspaper in the early days had many difficulties—but was of inestimable benefit to the country it served. Father, James Oliver, Melton Ford Davis and others helped—

Sincerely,

Dr. Gertrude Smith

Dear Mrs. Smith:

Your letter of April 28th, 1953, offering to complete an Archives Questionnaire, has been received. This offer is very welcome indeed, as your father was a very prominent pioneer, and any information which you can shed on the early experiences of your family will be valuable. General Questionnaire #2 is enclosed herewith.

There are also a number of special questions regarding the Times which you may be able to answer, in order to supplement the data which we already have regarding this paper:

1. Why did Thos. Spink decide to give up his partnership in the Times in 1884?
2. What members of your family were connected with the publishing of the paper both before and after your father's death?
3. Was your father able to earn a living from the newspaper and job printing business alone, in the early days?
4. Who gathered the Prince Albert town news?
5. Did you have personal relations with any of the other early editors, such as Laurie at Battleford or Robt. Jardine of the Saskatchewan (Prince Albert)?
6. From where did your 'boiler plate' or 'Patent insides' come from and how expensive was it?
7. How large was the paper's circulation and in what areas did it circulate outside Prince Albert itself?
8. Do you know anything about rival papers published in Prince Albert, called the Critic (1886-89) edited by Alex Stewart, or the Farratt (1881) edited by T. O. Davis?
9. How large a staff did the Times have, and did the number increase or decrease through the years?
10. Do you recall what your father's editorial policy was with respect to the Louis Riel agitation in 1884?

Dear Mrs. Smith:

Your letter of April 28th, 1953, referring to complete an archives questionnaire, has been received. This offer is very welcome indeed, as your father was a very prominent pioneer, and any information which you can send on the early experiences of your family will be valuable.

General Questionnaire #2 is enclosed herewith.

There are also a number of special questions regarding the Times which you may be able to answer in order to supplement the data given we already have regarding this paper:

1. Why did Thomas Spink decide to give up his partnership in the Times in 1884?
2. What members of your family were connected with the publishing of the paper both before and after your father's death?
3. Was your father able to earn a living from the newspaper and job printing business alone, in the early days?
4. Also gathered the Prince Albert town news?
5. Did you have personal relations with any of the other early editors, such as Laurier at Battleford or Robb, Jardine of the Saskatchewan (Prince Albert)?
6. From where did your "hotter plates" or "Patent Linotype" come from and how expensive was it?
7. How large was the paper's circulation and in what areas did it circulate outside Prince Albert itself?
8. Do you know anything about rival papers published in Prince Albert, called the Critic (1886-99) edited by Alex Stewart, or the Patriot (1881) edited by T.O. Davis?
9. How large a store did the Times have, and did the number increase or decrease through the years?
10. Do you recall what your father's editorial policy was with respect to the Louis Riel agitation in 1884?
Dear Mr. -

I read in the recent copy of the Calgary Herald that you were collecting data on pioneers of Saskatchewan. Roy Fulton, the late John D. Macleay started a paper in Prince Albert, Sask., in 1882 and our family grew up there and were educated in the schools etc. I was not young age when we went there - but have many recollections nearly deep (left there when I moved in 1901) and would be glad to fill out a questionnaire.

M. Gertrude Macleay Smith

Mrs. Alison Smith, 284-6 & 8
Medicine Hat

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (✓) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
(✓) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
(✓) Pioneer housing
(✓) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Margaret Smith
2. Your address: 64 Main Street, Medicine Hat, Alta.
3. Date: May 15, 1953
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Born in York June 1868
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   John Smith, farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   July 1870
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   "I was in my teens", etc.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child".
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   My parents came to help me
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

By living in it
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
My mother and her people were very much opposed to her coming with her children to the west.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
With the family - father, Lord, John, and two sisters early in '42 and moved on to the Prairies.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
We came from Toronto by rail to St. Paul and proceeded north by stage by railway.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
These are incidents from our journey as I was told by my parents. We kept Emerson Man as soon as navigation opened (May) after having collected provisions, equipment, and supplies. We went on the boat to Amblerland where they were entertained for a couple days by H.B.C. Factor Blanger who was very kind. Later on in the journey, the whale became too cold for the steamboat, and the family and equipment were loaded into your boat which proceeded to Fort Ed Come. Then fallen through a broken board and lean, and drove the last 48 miles to P.A.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
We rented a house from George MacKay. The family lived upstairs and the lower floor was used as an office.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
We never did take up land and always lived in P.A.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
My husband and I came to Medicine Hat in March 1903. Came in 1922 to pursue practice of his profession (dentistry) in Medicine Hat until he retired in 1948.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
Father was on the Toronto Telegram for several years - previous to that he worked on the Kingston Post Office. He was born in Kingston (in 1838) as was my mother.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

My mother said she thought it was a good idea.

12. Did you travel by train or by car?

We traveled by train from Toronto to Winnipeg, then by car to our children's home.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We came from Toronto by rail in 9 panels and proceeded north by CPR - by railways.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other incidents, etc.)

There are memories of my journey as we traveled by rail, having cattle, purchasing equipment and supplies near Old Hespell, Saskatchewan. We met new acquaintances along the way, including a family who provided us with food and shelter until we arrived in Saskatchewan.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We stayed at a farm for several weeks before going on to our homestead.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

We settled and started land in P.A.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

My husband and I came to Medicine Hat in 1908. Later in 1922 we moved to Medicine Hat until we retired in 1947.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I worked as a telegrapher in Calgary, Alberta, and later as a housewife in Medicine Hat.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Very frequently.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

My husband, Dr. Allan Smith, in H. Albert Church.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

No, they knew I didn't know anything about farming, and they never came.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Except my older brother and my very dear mother, the seven other members of the family—three brothers and four sisters—were born in Prince Albert.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

I remember starting school with my mother when I was very small and going to Mrs. Baker, a Presbyterian mission teacher—a year or so later we got a man teacher, Mr. J.A. Stull. He always thrilled us by telling us he was related to Laura Secord. Although until about 1895—Colin became postmaster, a very fine man. By 1895 he had an east end school, a room, next to the school, a room, back, a Presbyterian academy, a convent, and Emmanuel College—where we educated!!!

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Our family did not travel much—railroad came in 1899 and later there was an occasional trip—father went to Legislative opening in Regina. Mother went to visit her mother in Toronto in 1906—Colin removed to Toronto in 1913—died there in 1928.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Very frequently.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

My husband is Allan Smith.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, who?

No, there was no one else.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Escape my older brother and myself. We were the only members of the family who came here.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

I remember starting school with my brother when I was very young and going to Owen Barrie's poetry lesson. I also remember a year or two later he got a man named Mr. J. A. O'Neil. He always talked about Kansas and Nebraska, but we never went there until along 1895-1896 because production was very poor then.

In 1895 he had an ear and looked 20 years but, two months before he came back to a nearby town, he died.

And Samuel Colly, because he educated me.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Our family did not travel much because we lived in a small town and didn't have enough money to travel.

25. What was your occupation at this time?

I worked as a teacher in Regina, Saskatchewan.

26. When did you move to Canada?

I moved to Canada in 1906.

27. When did you die?

I died in 1928.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 
   *About 1908. U-Was owned by Judge T. McGurk.*

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   *My husband and I came to Medicine Hat and arrived in 1903. Bought a M. Longley car in 1914.*

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   *In Prince Albert. The trading was done at local stores (H.B.C., Loblaw, J.E. Barge and T.O. Davis).*

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   *As early as I can remember, it was possible to buy a good variety of goods in P.A. The H.B.C. was always wonderfully stocked. Fresh fruit was not what we had—like in apple season, etc.—until after the train came in in 1899.*

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   *I don't remember exactly how often. We were always living in town.*

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since then.
   *I remember Eaton's Catalogue coming out. It was quite small—likely 1892 or 93—and we did buy quite freely as goods, especially fancy items, were so much cheaper. Likely nearly half of our clothing was purchased that way. No ready-made clothing except knit underwear. Most made even the boys' clothes.*

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   *First telephones began in 1895. Then U.W. Bell phone.*

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   *We never came to Saskatchewan in the early days with the intention of staying. It was to make some money and go back east—and a lot did too. We stayed because we were anchored. One did not move easily in newspaper business.*

49. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

I have five children - all married:
Gertude Davidson - graduate in law - married in Toronto
Phyllis McNaughton - graduate teacher and nurse - married Bryan
Cecil Allan - married - real estate owner - married lives in Calgary
Patricia Phipps - teacher - secretary - married lives in Winnipeg
Lenore Garrett - graduate nurse - married lives in New Mexico
Grandchildren: Harold McNaughton, Peter Bryan and Linda Smith

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

I cannot tell all the ways how developed marvellously. I remember Prince Albert was a beautiful modern city, Saskatoon (remember when it had about 3 buildings) a lovely and growing city. Regina just a little town as far as I know. Now a beautiful and thriving city.
